This shot is really neat.  I'd love to see any additional information on the colorization process as well.

(Great to see you join the Commons!)

comment.author: 65538230@N00
comment._content:
The USS Olympia is docked at Penns Landing in Philadelphia PA, USA
I have some arial shots of it taken in the 1970s . One recent shot on flicker taken at a distance

comment.author: 26887305@N00
comment._content: MargaretsFamily: "And the generals beside them?" That's General John J. Pershing, second from the right, he was the commander of the American Expeditionary Force. Rich Snyder: ".I always thought the earliest color photos were from the 1940s." Color photography was even done back in the 19th century actually. :)

comment.author: 14662771@N00
comment._content: Poignant shot, immediately brings to life the things I read about in Neil Hanson's excellent factual WW1 book 'The Unknown Soldier'. -- http://blog.flickr.net/en/2009/04/14/dc-public-library-joins-the-commons/ (?)

comment.author: 22527577@N03
comment._content:
The thing about the coloring process that I think is neat is that this picture really looks like a blending and combination of photograph and painting. Perhaps that is just from the fact that it actually is (a B&W picture with the color painted on it)... but still very cool!

By the way, is this dock still there... as in could it be geotagged?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: This photograph was taken at the old dock of Washington Navy Yard shortly after 8 bells, or 4 o'clock, on Wednesday November 9, 1921. The group of officials at the right, including Pershing are from left to right: Secretary Weeks Secretary Denby General Pershing Admiral Coontz. A full account of the dramatic and moving ceremony of disembarkation can be found in the New York Times of the next day here: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A04E3DD1539E1...
